text:
Well, I would be remiss if I
didn't say it's a Section B day.
All right.

OK, Section B. Thank
you so much, Katie.

I so much appreciate
that introduction.

And I am delighted to join
faculty members, friends, family

here today to celebrate the
next generation of leaders,

innovators, and my hope for
a better tomorrow, also known
as the Class of 2024.
Come on, yes, yes!

It's hard for me to believe it's
been almost 40 years ago since I

walked on campus as
a first year student.
I know.
I know.
You don't have to say it.
Swipe Eric.
I look pretty damn good.

The feeling I have right
now is so familiar to me.

It's a feeling of exhilaration,
of humbleness, and nervousness.

It's exactly how I felt
on my first day of class.

It was marketing,
and we'd already
been assigned a case study.

The subject was
Freemark Abbey, a winery

facing the usual challenges
associated with farming, like I

knew anything about
farming, weather, brand
management, and distribution.

Rumors that night
spread pretty quickly

that a military guy would
be chosen to open the case.
So I knew that wasn't me.

In our section, he
spoke with confidence.

His discipline, training,
and steadfastness all
shined through.

This only made me
more terrified.

When he finished, the
professor opened the floor.

I had thoughts on the
case, but I was just too
intimidated to raise my hand.

I was frozen by
overwhelming concern.
Would my comments be additive?
Were they smart?

I flashed back to
when I was six.

Dropping me off at first grade,
my father whispered to me,
we are counting on you.
Make us proud.

That thought even
terrified me more.

Sometimes we apply so
much pressure on ourselves

to achieve perfection that
we lose the real growth
opportunities along the way.

I kept my mouth shut and did not
speak in that first marketing
class.

But sitting through
a few more classes

and getting to
know my classmates,

I realized what felt like
a weakness was actually
a strength.

Yes, it was important
that my voice was heard,

and I did learn to
comment in class.

But it was also key
that I listened.

I already knew what I
thought about the case.

So hearing what others
thought broadened

my base of understanding and
that included opinions that I
did not always agree with.

And as it worked out,
that impulse to listen

would not only make
me a better leader,

but also help to make me
a better person, friend,
and parent.

Our idiosyncrasies
create pressure and fear,
but they also motivate us.

Understand what yours
are and fight always
to keep them in perspective.

Now, these days,
I know maintaining

perspective can be a little
tough, especially when optimism
is in such short supply.

For the first time in the
12 year history of the World

Happiness Report, America
did not rank in the top 20.

Anyone here from Finland,
Denmark, or Iceland?
Anyone?
I don't see anybody.
Maybe.
They finished 1, 2, and 3.
America dropped to 23.

This included a significant
decline of reported well-being
among Americans under 30.

I think it's really no secret
that younger Americans are

struggling with
mental health issues.

The digital age has altered
the world dramatically,

while the real world has served
up a series of unending traumas
for millennials, 9/11--
all right, bee--

Katrina, mass shootings,
George Floyd, COVID,
and the Ukrainian war.

These unprecedented macro
realities are the new normal,

adding another layer to what has
become an increasingly complex
and swiftly changing world.

In the face of these ever
shifting changes and challenges,

it can be hard to discern where
to focus, what's important.
How are you going to add value?

How will you curate
a life that reflects

not just what the workplace
values, but what you value?

And my favorite question,
one that I ask myself often,

what is your
framework for holding
yourself accountable for good?

Your ability to work from this
personal framework for good

will impact your success,
but most important,
your ultimate happiness.

The 2024 Trust Barometer
Study, conducted by Edelman,

identified innovation as the key
to the next era of prosperity.

At the same time,
innovation is what

has amplified
political polarization
and societal instability.

In the US, we're seeing
this come true every day

with the Republicans
pushing for less regulations

while trying to rally pockets
of Americans that are feeling

disenfranchised, often using
the misguided threat of AI
as a surrogate.

On the other hand,
Democrats are continuing

to be seen as absorbed with
more limited liberal causes that

have not traditionally
been valued

or interesting to the
majority of white men.

According to the
study, individuals

are looking for business leaders
to ensure that innovation

has been evaluated by
scientists and ethicists,

is effectively regulated, and
does not have control over how
their lives are impacted.

This foreshadows
the demand that will

be synonymous with excellence
in business leadership.

We already see how
business leaders

like Jamie Dimon and others
navigate politics and world
affairs.

As the lines blur,
CEOs are asked

to make decisions
that might appear

to be outside of the
boundaries of their jobs.

Just look at the recent examples
and decisions of two CEOs,
McDonald's and Google.

McDonald's closed all
of its restaurants

in Russia after the country
instigated an attack on Ukraine.

And Google is still
today navigating

employee demands associated
with Israel and Gaza.

You don't have to agree
with their decisions.
That's really not the point.

Toni Morrison once said
"the grandeur of life
is that attempt.

It's not always about
the perfect solution.

It is about being as fearless
as one can be and behaving

as beautifully as one can
under completely impossible
circumstances."
Good is just more interesting.
It's more complex.

Today I stand before you not
only as a businesswoman, but as

a storyteller, an
observer of life

and the many twists and
turns that it offers.

Sometimes you can have your most
difficult challenges at a time

that you also have the
most to celebrate, Eric.
Life is funny that way.

It's hardly ever
all good or all bad.

When I was at HBS,
many of my classmates

went into investment
banking and consulting.

My path would be
different, focused

on taking a line position
offer in Chicago where I would
gain experience managing teams.

At the time, it seemed like
an odd choice, but not to me.

One of my favorite
lines in a movie

is the nosy lady on the train of
the original Coming to America,

who says to Lisa, a main
character, "Honey, go on, honey.
Take a chance."

I feel like I've
been taking chances

all of my life, an
approach that was

amplified by a bout with
cancer almost 20 years ago.

Nothing made it clearer
than life is a gift
and not guaranteed.

People claim they wanted to
hear my distinct point of view,

but that's not
always been the case.

So the trick has been to ensure
value was added before there
was too much rejection.

This became a theme for me
across the multiple industries
that I've invaded--
I did say invade--

including telecommunications,
gaming, utilities, insurance,

government, publishing,
and now cosmetics.

I'm not going to stand here
and talk to you about my rise
through corporate America.

But I am going to focus
on a massive shift that

has occurred in my thinking that
reinforces the notion of good,

especially when everything
seems to be going wrong.

In other words, the importance
of wrong to get to right.

With a bit of luck
and lots of hard work,
I was on a roll, that is.

It all came to a halt
at the White House.
In 2029-- I'm sorry-- in 2009--
I'm speeding up my time here--

President Barack
Obama, as you've heard,

offered me the job of Special
Assistant and White House Social
Secretary.

It was an offer, as they
say, I just couldn't refuse.

Excited to be a part of
history, serve my country,

and support my
friend, I moved to DC.

I approached government as I did
every other industry I entered.

Study, look for
opportunities, and put
in the hours, the HBS way.

The big idea, my big
idea was to create

the people's house, where
equity, inclusion, and hope were
central.

I immediately hired an
advertising executive,

and one of my best friends
who's sitting over here,

an Obama policy expert, to
lead our work dividing events

into historical
and nonhistorical.

We spent all of our time
reimagining the experiences

that visitors would
have at the White House.

How could we bring aspects of
the Obama presidency to life?
Think about collaborations.

For example, one version
of a poetry jam that we did

included Othello with James
Earl Jones performing,

and then Lin-Manuel
Miranda performing,

for the very first
time, Hamilton.

I was surprised to learn when
I got there that the Easter Egg

Roll was limited
to people waiting

in line from the
surrounding areas

and tickets being assigned on a
first come, first served basis.
So guess what?
Lottery was in my background.
We did a lottery.

And we increased the number of
people that attended four times,

as well as ensuring participants
from all 50 states arrived.
We added sushi.

I know, sounds like crazy, to
the traditional holiday press

party of turkey and ham, along
with news guru and mixologist
Rachel Maddow.
Who knew she could mix a drink?

And it wasn't just
Rachel Maddow.
We were mixing things up.
It was exciting.
It was fresh.

And that's when I learned
that not everyone likes
exciting and fresh.

I was so focused on doing what I
had done so successfully before

that I misread the culture
and their appetite for change.

With the administration
making an all hands effort

to pass the
Affordable Care Act, I

could not imagine
that the press would

be so interested in
the social office.
Never underestimate the press.

What I had not
realized was that this

was historical Washington,
built on tradition and politics.

With divisive politics
taking the lead,

there was never a moment
where someone was not looking
to embarrass the president.

With any president,
this is fair play.

But serving the first Black
president, the room for error

felt narrowed, and tension
was particularly acute.

Heck, they attacked him
for wearing a tan suit.

And they attacked me for messing
with history and for two reality

stars showing up at the
gate and crashing their way

into an official state
dinner on my watch.

I was out on my
ass in 15 months.
The headlines were brutal.

Every news outlet
was in hot pursuit

to speak to me about
what went wrong.

No one cared about
what went right.

In Hidden Potential,
authored by Adam Grant,

he talks about the importance
of character skills,

scaffolding, and systems
designed to nurture.

He writes, "Character is often
confused with personality,
but they're not the same.

Personality is your
predisposition,

your basic instincts for
how to think, feel, or act.

Character is your capacity to
prioritize your values over
your instincts."

My personality was desperate
to convince everyone
that I had followed protocol.

I even wanted to testify
in front of Congress
about the gatecrashers.

Today, we all know how badly
congressional hearings can go,

and in the process, leaders
can be forced to resign.

But ultimately, my
values led the way.

There was a greater good
that had to be protected.

So I walked away
from a job I loved,

but not before I assured my team
that we had followed procedure
to the letter.

And when the Secret Service
arrived the next day

to apologize, I still
held myself to account.

My values ultimately
drove my behavior.

I've come to believe
that perhaps the only way

to get to a lot of rights is
to experience a lot of wrongs.

Class of 2024, I know
that you will be fearless.

I know that you
will scatter and do

the good work that the
world requires and deserves.
Be the good trouble makers.

Congressman John Lewis
said to me once or twice,

"It's important to engage
in good trouble, Desiree.
It's the necessary trouble."

I believe that you guys are
brave enough, smart enough,

and equipped to inspire
bold, thoughtful leadership
at the dawn of your careers.

Start now rather than waiting
to achieve society's stamp
of approval for success.

The issues confronting us
are enormous and growing,

war, racial, and class
unrest, social injustice,

environmental destruction, book
banning, and the elimination
of individual rights.

I can't help but notice that all
of this is happening at a time

when diversity, equity and
inclusion have supposedly
become more than buzzwords.
But have they really?
Have we really made progress?
I do know one thing for sure.

We will not be able
to move forward

if we can't sit down
and civilly debate
the important issues of our day.

But then, you have been
trained to do just that.

You can forget everything
you learned in fintech,
but don't forget that.

In closing, I must go
back to Toni Morrison.
"Evil is not a compelling idea.
It's predictable."

On the other hand, survival,
blossoming, endurance,

those things are more
compelling intellectually,
if not spiritually.

It's just a more
fascinating job.
We are already born.
We are already going to die.

We must do something interesting
that is respected in between.
Thank you so much.
[APPLAUSE]
